Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Role and Formation of Tyrosine-Cysteine Protein Cofactors
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will investigate the ability of tyrosine and cysteine sidechains of proteins to crosslink through an arylalkylthioether bond (abbreviated as Tyr-Cys). Tyr-Cys crosslinks participate in oxidation catalysis and are formed by two proton-coupled oxidations. Metal-oxygen chemistry and the correct sidechain geometries are necessary for Tyr-Cys crosslink formation. Only four examples have been identified using X-ray crystallography that suggests limitations from the chemistry, sidechain geometries, or detection methods. A search of all protein structures in the protein databank showed many proteins with appropriate sidechain geometries for Tyr-Cys crosslink formation. Based on conditions for dityrosine formation, the chemistry for Tyr-Cys should be facile under biological conditions. Tyr-Cys identification by X-ray crystallography, however, requires careful analysis of high-resolution data. In order in better identify Tyr-Cys crosslinks a proteolysis and HPLC separation method will be employed using mass spectrometry and nuclear magnetic resonance detection. Cysteine dioxygnease contains a Tyr-Cys crosslink and will be examined for method validation. The three other proteins where Tyr-Cys have not been previously observed will be used to test if the combination of these detection methods and a previous protein databank search will expand the number of Tyr-Cys crosslinks simply examining static protein structure. This information, along with reexamining the function of Tyr-Cys in cystiene dioxygenase, will determine if the biological scope of Tyr-Cys containing proteins is significantly broader than currently thought.

Broader impacts of this award come from the potential to expand the biological scope of the Tyr-Cys crosslink and parent crosslinked protein derived cofactors. Additionally, this award will use NSF-supported instrumentation and a newly renovated interdisciplinary laboratory. This work will prepare four undergraduate chemistry/biochemistry majors for graduate work in areas related to protein chemistry. This award will also provide indirect training for up to ten additional undergraduate researchers in a shared interdisciplinary research lab. Two high school students who are underrepresented minorities in the sciences will be mentored by the PI and co-PI in conjunction with ACS Project SEED.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Antioxidants are small molecules that give up an electron when needed to protect the body or another organism. This is why daily doses of antioxidants from foods, vitamins, and health supplements are beneficial. This work looked at a class of naturally occurring chemical modifications to proteins (a large molecule) that serve the same function as antioxidants; that they give up an electron when needed. We believe these modified proteins can have antioxidant abilities in their local environments since these modified proteins will be at a much lower concentration and not diffuse as fast as small molecule antioxidants. These protein modifications would, however, provide protection for the local environment so proteins can do their intended work without being consumed by species that have a high affinity of electrons (called reactive oxygen species).

 

The primary barrier to this field advancing is detecting these modified proteins. This work has developed a fluorescence detection method for a protein thought to have one of these modifications. This method is far more routine than the current method, X-ray crystallography which requires at least 6 months and expensive resources. The fluorescence method developed does require one day for data collection and analysis but provides a means to measure the percentage of total protein converted to modified protein.

 

Developing the fluorescence assay was enabled by the prediction of another protein that forms one of these modifications. This protein was predicted by a search of an international database of protein structures (protein databank, www.rcsb.org). The protein we identified was deposited to this databank but not published since it was found by researchers looking for novel protein structures. The protein from a gene product of a gut bacteria (Bacteroides fragilis) that had a novel combination of amino acid building blocks that make a protein unique (primary structure). Since there is no known function of this protein we only have the gene product as the name BF4112(gene product 4112 from B. fragilis). This protein did form the chemical modification that we predicted, which was confirmed by ultraviolet absorbance, fluorescence, and mass spectrometric methods. Because BF4112 is smaller than most proteins known to contain this modification, we were able to measure the percentage of total protein converted to modified protein by ultraviolet absorbance. This then allowed us to correlate the ultraviolet absorbance yields that only work with BF4112 with the developed fluorescence method which will apply to many more proteins.

 

This fluorescence method has allowed us to look at additional formation chemistries, protein candidates, and faster detection methods. Using BF4112, we have determined that proteins with single iron and copper ions can generate these modifications, even if the modified residues are not bonded to each other. This finding expands the number of potential proteins that can form this modification. We are also examining additional protein candidates, were we have identified a protein that could have already formed this modification but has not been reported that way. The difficulty is understanding the formation chemistry in this case as the protein does not contain a iron or copper protein. Finally, we are looking at small molecules that will form a bond with these modifications when they give up an electron. These small molecules can then be used to purify these modified proteins to measure yield and isolate modified proteins directly from biological samples. These additional methods, enabled by our fluorescence assay, are currently being investigated and the topic for additional proposed funding.

 


Last Modified: 03/17/2016
Modified by: David E Benson
